ğŸª The Self Layer â€“ Core of Your Psyche



Why the Self?

The Self is the core framework of who we are â€” the internal structure that organizes thought, feeling, and growth.
It is not about performance or outward roles, but the living center that anchors your psyche.

The Self remains when masks are set aside and outer personas shift.
It guides Shadow work, informs choices, and allows your Persona expressions to adapt without losing balance.

Understanding the Self is the starting point for maturity: without a stable center, any outer expression can feel ungrounded.



The Backbone of the Model

This framework emphasizes three primary voices in the study of Self:

  • Carl Jung, M.D. â†’ Originator of cognitive function theory (introversion, extraversion, thinking, feeling, sensing, intuition). His work remains the philosophical and psychological root.
  • John Beebe, M.D. â†’ Expanded Jungâ€™s work into the 8-function archetype model, mapping both conscious and shadow functions.
  • Dario Nardi, Ph.D. â†’ Neuroscientist whose EEG research provides biological evidence of cognitive functions in real-time brain activity.

Together, they form a tested, flexible backbone for Self analysis â€” psychological depth, archetypal framing, and neuroscientific support.

What About Other Models?

Personality theory has spawned countless systems. While valuable, many:

  • Oversimplify Jungâ€™s insights into static stereotypes.
  • Overcomplicate without clarity, creating endless labels.
  • Stay surface-level, focusing on traits rather than processes.

This space doesnâ€™t reject those models â€” but it anchors in Jung, Beebe, and Nardi as the most fertile ground for Self exploration.
Other systems are like side-paths: interesting to visit, but not the core map.



References

  • Jung, C. G. (1968). *The Archetypes and the Collective Unconscious* (Collected Works, Vol. 9, Part 1). Princeton University Press.
    â†’ Explores archetypes and unconscious patterns that shape personality and behavior.
  • Jung, C. G. (1963). *Memories, Dreams, Reflections*. Vintage Books.
    â†’ Jungâ€™s reflections on personal development, individuation, and self-awareness.
  • Beebe, J. (1994). *Integrity in Depth: Archetypal Explorations of the Persona, Shadow, and Complexes*. Routledge.
    â†’ Provides insight into the Persona, Shadow, and archetypal dynamics in everyday life.
  • Nardi, D. (2011). *Neuroscience of Personality: Brain-Savvy Insights for All Types of People*. Radiance House.
    â†’ Maps cognitive patterns to brain activity, showing how personality types influence behavior and interactions.
